comments.commentBody: The problem is not how much you make, but what you do to make it. You practice crisis medicine, which is a model that was foisted upon society by your predecessors in the medical societies of the last century. It's a model that concentrates power over health decisions in the hands of the initiates (MDs) while denying that same power to the rest of us. It does this by brutally suppressing alternative models, belittling the innate understanding of one's body through "patient management" and by spreading fear of natural processes and the idea that individuals are powerless in the face of disease.

We have to give credit where it is due... Bill Gates is who talked Warren Buffett into giving away most of his money. Pretty amazing, huh?

Our work as voters has only just begun. We need to help President Obama cement his legacy by cleaning out the dry rot at the midterms.

Particular characteristics of the sample size (72 older, sedentary women) mean that these findings may not be generalizable. Significant physiological differences in metabolism, capacity for muscle mass and tissue repair etc could lead to different results in younger people or in men.

What is kind of ironic is that I eat many of the same kinds of food you eat, but at a higher calorie level.  I consume 4 ounces of nuts each day , plus two tablespoons of ground flaxseed, plus two tablespoons of peanut butter and this alone amounts to almost 1000 calories.  I really do need to eat this many nuts, in order to get enough protein in my diet, since I don't eat meat and very, very little dairy and few eggs. Since I eat partly at work (food service in a nursing home) and I am not always able to eat beans everyday.   If I eat beans and rice, I eat about one cup of each of these and these with the sauces amounts to 600 calories.  Two big bananas that I may eat can amount to 300 calories.  I eat far fewer desserts than I used to eat and while I can stop eating chocolate once I start, I am beginning to be more concerned about the trans and saturated fats contained in them.  Monounsaturated and omega 3 fat is far healthier.  I have also stopped drinking diet sodas as well.   I really does take more than 1250 calories to get enough nutrition, except possibly if one eats a lot of non starchy vegetables.  On a near Vegan diet, it is very hard to get enough protein on that calorie level.   Even though 3500 calories sounds like a lot, it certainly isn't all that I would eat if I let myself go.  I am 52 now and I have to exercise a lot more than I ever did to keep my metabolism up.  I would rather do that than to eat less to maintain my 158 weight at 6 foot.

Totally agree. I love my stationary bike, kinect, and my exercise ball. I am not crazy about weight lifting exercises but they are very important.
Sometimes my favorite exercise is just turning on the ipod and doing a little boogying. In the meantime family members have a good laugh but I don't mind.
This isn't silly and the experiment may have flaws, but it's a serious attempt to figure out what works.

Yes, that is the bottomline isn't it?  I strongly agree.  You definately hit it on the nose!  Those rates are actually not bad when one could consider a likely increase of drivers may be distracted by the new electronic devices while operating their cars/trucks, involved with those motorcycle accidents.  Let us also consider that their is probably an increase of more aged people driving their cars around with physical and cognitive impairments.  There is also another possible factor adding into the mix of motorcycle accidents and injuries: maybe there is more potholes and road debris from less funds available for maintaining the roadways.  Lots of factors could be involved.

If one looks at their numbers, they suggest no rise in accidents among older drivers, not an increase! The proportion of older riders have increased from 10% of motorcyclists to 25%,, more than doubling, yet the accident rate has only gone up 145%, about the same proportion as the rise in the in proportion of older drivers!

The rest of the article makes sense., but there is a lot of individual variation.

This research is interesting. Someone in my family is suffering from enlarged heart condition which makes even walking from room to room hard. It was caused my daily heavy smoking and drinking for 30+ years. For this reason I take my blood pressure readings every week just for interest as im under 30.

This is useful if you want to take your own blood pressure:
http://clickhowto.com/how-to-take-your-own-blood-pressure/

“'We think that the women in the twice-a-week and four-times-a-week groups felt more energized and physically capable”  It appears that the researchers could not distinguish between changes in resting energy expenditure (metabolic rate + digestion + thermogenesis) and activity levels while unsupervised.  It could very well be the case that the increased energy burned by the more frequent exercisers was the result of an increase in their resting rate of energy expenditure.  Some studies have shown an increase in energy expenditure several hours following exercise even when there was no increase in typical non-exercise activity levels.  The fact that the researches failed to measure resting energy expenditure of their test subjects on a regular basis, which is not at all difficult to do these days is a major weakness of this study.

A few years ago, I switched from teaching my, "Safe Strength Training for Osteoporosis Prevention" classes from 3 days a week to 2 days. My class participants and clients are generally between the age of 50 and 75. Many of us weren't feeling fully recovered with only 48 hours between workouts. 72 hours seemed to do the trick.

Other research supports twice-weekly strength training as optimal for those in the over-fifty age group. That schedule provides plenty of time for other aerobic, heart-healthy types of activities.
I always assumed that person with Acute Kidney Failure would need to be hospitalized due to the underlying cause of AKF.
That's admirable.  If you really still want to lose the weight, read Gary Taubes' "Why We Get Fat."
The donors were tested.

Lisa, at our milk bank we believe that moms’ milk is always best for babies.  We are sending milk out to the most fragile babies. Multiple studies show that pasteurized donor milk can save the life of preterm infants with  immature guts and immune systems. We screen our donors and pasteurize our milk to ensure the safety of compromised infants, and we pass it along at our cost of processing because our mission is to provide this critical nutrient to every infant who can benefit; not to make a profit. We are grateful for mothers who have extra milk and are willing to donate it to non-profit milk banks that serve preterm infants (and we’re making the process as easy as possible with a quick phone screen and medical history. Then we provide containers and cover shipping costs). As more hospitals realize that donor milk is like medicine for preterm infants, demand is surging past supply and we welcome new donors -www.mothersmilk.org.

Good point. I wonder what kind of lean muscle mass changes the different groups ended up with. That would be nice to know, given the increasing risks of sarcopenia as we age.

Also kudos for pointing out that significant gains in muscle depend on moving the kind of poundage that you can't recover from in a day. As they say, you don't stronger by working out; you get stronger by *recovering* from your workout.

I think @striving's answer is correct.  There's much more money in telling people "a calorie is a calorie" and "everything in moderation," since it lets processed food corporations make millions selling 100-calorie packs & "diet" versions of their usual fare.  No one gets rich telling people that processed food & refined carbs are all bad, even if it's true.
The notion that red meat is an "empty-calorie food" is rather amusing.  Ever hear of protein?  B-12?  Iron?  Omega-3 fatty acids?

@RossWilliams Gary Taubes also has an M.A. in astrophysics, and spent years researching the subjects he wrote about. Any intelligent person ought to be able to understand the relevant science after learning that much about it -- let along a writer with an advanced science degree. Presumably you would't bash Taubes' credentials if he had a Ph.D. in nutrition, yet such a degree wouldn't confer any magical ability to understand the deep meaning of empirical studies.

The scientific method isn't like gnosticism. If your claims make sense, they should be comprehinsible to anyone (even a journalist!).

And these "facts" come from.......where exactly? Your own personal observation?

Are you aware that AA actually did a survey in the 70s at Harvard and their own scientist determined that the success rate was only 5%? Even Bill W. himself claimed that the success rate was only about 20% (and we all know that honesty wasn't Bill's strong point, so we can assume that this was already an inflated figure).

Why can't 12 steppers admit that the program may work for a limited number of people but this does not mean that the program "works if you work it"? This is deeply insulting to the people for whom the program doesn't work, which is, in fact the majority of people - which probably explains why 12 steppers felt the need to come up with this tired "it works if you work it" cliche in the first place as a defense against the real statistics.

Why must 12 steppers add insult to injury by insisting that if the program doesn't work for you, then it's because there is something wrong with the person, never the program? This is an addict's thought process and the fact that so many people in 12 step programs spout this nonsense only proves how ineffective AA really is. If the program made people emotionally healthy (rather than making them dry drunks constantly on the verge of relapse) then AA members wouldn't feel the need to walk around wagging their fingers at people who disagree with their methodology. Really, only people in cults behave this way.

HKGuy: Your comment was exactly what I neglected to mention in my earlier comment about my six-times-a-week workout schedule. I do upper body MWF and lower body TuThSat so every part gets a day to recover. I no longer do cardio/aerobic exercise as I find that weight resistance, done properly, serves my cardio needs. That plus meat and fat; I'm having a great time.
Debbie R. in Brookline, MA: Really excellent deduction; I like the way you think.
The pharmaceutical and medical products industries sell their products on more nebulous studies.

"Why doesn't everyone just take responsibility for themselves, go to work, and put their health at the top of their priority list instead of vacations, eating out, fashionable clothes etc... You want good health care, doctors ought to be paid at the top of the food chain."

I am supposed to beggar myself to keep you on the "top of the food chain?" Who is the entitled one here?

Overall you make good points but FYI Brucellosis is not rampant in the US cow population, it has been virtually eradicated by government programs and is a reportable disease. Cow milk does carry all kinds of other potential pathogens like Staphylococcus (including resistant species), Coxiella, enteric bacteria, etc. If you have ever milked a cow, you know they often have poop all over their udders. I pumped my own milk for the better part of a year and can honestly say I never got poop anywhere near my breasts.

@BeadyEye --

Technical matters re: firearms arcana are really not the issue, are they? While they may make you feel momentarily superior, in much the way shouldering your guns probably do, offering up technicalities adds absolutely nothing to the serious discussion about gun homicides and the havoc they wreak in a supposedly advanced, civilized nation.

The grown ups are having a discussion here, in an attempt to find solutions that will satisfy those who earnestly wish to diminish the carnage and also permit those obsessed with the notion that 2nd Amendment rights trump all others to continue to keep and bear SOME arms.

You clearly have no interest in this discussion, so why not march on over to the NRA site and continue your advanced course in obstructionism?
